Articles
Space Systems
The Space Systems division builds and launches CubeSats for scientific missions - our main goal is to provide educational opportunities to students in spacecraft design, assembly, testing, operation, mission planning and leadership.
We are passionate about designing systems that test novel designs, address scientific gaps, and help life on Earth improve. Our designs are open-source for other teams to improve on; our division is fully student-funded the University of Toronto Engineering Society (EngSoc).
UTAT Space Systems is a no-barrier team - we recruit from all engineering disciplines and from other faculties as well, to pull together a wide knowledge base. We believe in giving members ownership of their works, and making sure that our members contribute uniquely to our missions.
Project Overview
FINCH
The
Field Imaging Nanosatellite for Crop residue Hyperspectral mapping
(FINCH)
mission is a 3U CubeSat mission designed to conduct a technological demonstration of crop residue mapping from the Low-Earth Orbit.
The two primary goals for this mission are:
Performing a technological demonstration of the first Volume Phase Holographic (VPH) grism in a small form-factor
Providing a proof of concept for crop residue mapping using hyperspectral short wave infrared
(SWIR) satellite remote sensing
Since 2020, the FINCH mission has gone through its mission scoping and high-level design phase. We are jumping into the detailed design phase now, full of rapid prototyping and proofs-of-concept in all areas of the team. FINCH is aiming to innovate with its novel payload design, and integrating high-performance components in all subsystems to make sure we get the best payload data we can.
FINCH is projected to launch in Q3 2028.
Development Timeline for FINCH
2019
- FINCH Kickoff! The name of the satellite is chosen from the Satellite Idea Competition
2020
- Space Systems chooses a remote sensing mission profile. Mission scoping begins
April 2021
- High-Level Design for FINCH begins
March 2022
- Detailed Design for FINCH begins
HERON Mk. II
The Space Systems division is proud to present the
HERON Mk. II
satellite, the first fully student-built and student-funded satellite in Canada.
HERON Mk. II was launched and deployed into Sun-synchronous orbit on November 11th, 2023, during the SpaceX Transporter-9 mission aboard a Falcon 9 rocket.
As primarily an educational and self-training mission, there have been many learnings along the way—developing an amateur radio ground station, establishing robust design and testing practices, and much more. As a secondary mission, HERON will validate our open-source electronics and mechanical design.
HERON’s mechanical design (MECH) includes a passive magnetic attitude control system, thermal insulation system, and standardized 3U CubeSat structural design. The main electronics design (BUS) includes an electrical power system with solar arrays, UHF band communication system, and on-board computer with custom firmware.
In 2021, the Space Systems division finished the development of the amateur radio satellite HERON in preparation for hand-off and launch. Since 2017, the team has been designing HERON as the team’s first-ever CubeSatellite in the hopes that future satellites and radio amateurs will use and modify our open-source designs.
Currently, the HERON project is focused on the launch and operations phase by coordinating with our launch provider and testing our own ground station. We are looking for members with programming experience, interest/experience in amateur radio communications, and an interest in spacecraft operations.
HERON acts as a WORD on the UHF band and is available to amateur radio operators across the world.
For more details on the satellite project, please consult the link below:
Our Website for HERON
Development Timeline for HERON Mk. II
2016-2018 -
Space Systems designs and builds HERON Mk. II for the 4th edition of the Canadian Satellite Design Challenge.
2017 -
Space Systems secures UTSU levy to fund launch of HERON Mk. II.
June 2018 -
HERON Mk. II vibration testing conducted at DFL as part of CSDC.
2019 -
Space Systems succeeds in getting UTSU levy renewed.
Fall 2019 -
HERON Mk. II softstack takes place.
February 2020 -
HERON Mk. II bakeout and TVAC conducted at MDA in Brampton, Ontario.
2021 -
Space Systems succeeds in getting UTSU levy renewed a second time.
March ~ April 2021 -
HERON Mk. II final assembly (hardstack) takes place.
June 2021 -
HERON Mk. II flight model vibration testing conducted at NTS in Kitchener, Ontario.
October 2021 -
Mission objectives changed to emphasize educational objective, in order to increase team’s experience with amateur radio communications.
Summer 2022 -
HERON ground station assembly begins
August 2023 -
HERON Mk. II deployer integration in Bellevue, Washington.
November 11th, 2023 -
Spacebound! HERON Mk. II launches from Vandenberg Space Force Base on the SpaceX Transporter-9 rideshare mission aboard a Falcon 9 rocket.
HERON Mk. I (Retired)
Development Timeline for HERON Mk. I
2014-2016 -
HERON Mk. I CubeSat developed and constructed
2017 -
Poster presentation at NASA AAQ in Huntsville, USA, followed by retirement of the demonstrator
Why Amateur Radio?
A key educational objective for the HERON Mk. II mission is to provide amateur radio training and amateur satellite operations experience to our members. To this end, we have a training program for UTAT Space Systems members that makes significant use of the Amateur Basic and Advanced content. While this training is primarily for new Communications members, others on the team are welcome to participate. It is our goal that HERON will further the development of the amateur radio community in Toronto and beyond: our designs are publicly available, and amateur operators from around the world will be able to receive telemetry data from HERON as well as use our ground station via the SatNOGS network.
New members learn the basics of RF Communications starting with the knowledge required for Basic licensure, and pass the Amateur Radio exam so they can operate our amateur ground station and help design RF components under the guidance of the Communications lead. Keener members are encouraged to study for the Advanced licensure as this content is what they will learn over the course of the HERON and FINCH missions, and will allow them to further assist with communications in the amateur band using our ground station.
Teams and Sub-teams
FINCH Sub-teams
Systems
The highway that links the team and the FINCH design. Manage design decisions and interfaces (points of connection) across FINCH using systems thinking, and making the assembly and testing plans for the satellite.
Science
The role of the Science sub-team is to develop rigorous methods of validating design decisions which affect the Scientific value of the satellite. These methods involve forward model simulations, the development of data analysis pipelines (including machine learning), and close cooperation with our partners at the Agriculture and Agri-Foods Canada (AAFC) and EMILI Agriculture Innovation for ground truth campaigns each Spring and Fall
Mission Operations
Collective of members who work together in collaboration with other subteams to establish how FINCH will work in space, and how that translates for the firmware, power, RF, electronics, and ADCS teams. We look at modes of operation and risk mitigation through FDIR/FMEA analysis to conduct a smooth mission.
Data Processing
Develop code in Python to correct various sources of noise in our data after it’s downlinked from FINCH.
Hardware
Develop the space-grade PCBs that will make FINCH work. From the schematic to board layout and testing, we design and test our boards in-house.
Firmware & CDH
(Command & Data Handling)
Write the code that keeps FINCH running. Working at a lower level than the software most people are familiar with, we build fast, reliable interfaces between power, the camera, sensors, actuators, radios, thermal, and more.
RF
(Radio Frequency)
Design and test the radio-frequency communications signal chain so we can command FINCH from the ground and pull data from the satellite.
Mechanical
Develop the satellite structure, ensuring everything fits and we follow the launch provider’s mass and volume requirements. Undertake vibration testing to ensure we can withstand the vibrations and forces that come with the launch!
Thermal
Protect FINCH against the crazy thermal loads on orbit and hold each component at optimal temperatures to make the satellite work. Put the satellite through thermal vacuum testing to verify its operations in space!
Opto-Mechanical
Optimechanical is focused on the design of the hyperspectral imager housing, where the magic happens! It contains the Payload Electronics and Optics teams. Recommended for those who want to learn about many satellite functions working together, and contribute to a cutting-edge payload design for scientific and technological research.
ADCS
(Attitude Determination and Control Systems)
Responsible for ensuring the spacecraft is pointed in the correct direction at any given time, using a system of sensors, actuators, and algorithms.
Power
Design and test the power generation, storage, and distribution circuits for FINCH.
How to Join
Space Systems accepts new members primarily during the first few weeks of September, January and May. To join during one of these primary onboarding cycles, please fill out the sign-up form linked below:
Sign-up Form
For any questions, or to join outside of primary onboarding times, please email the Director of Space Systems at
spacesys@utat.ca
No applications or resumes are required!
Just let us know what your interests are, and we will help you get onboard during the next recruitment cycle.

Overview
This short guide presents a quick and dirty introduction to the FINCH mission and the spacecraft we’re building to tackle the mission (spoilers, there are no birds involved). This guide is only updated during recruitment cycles. For the source truth of the design, refer to the
Requirements
or speak with the system leads.
For team-specific onboarding, refer to the onboarding materials on the
Teams
homepages. For a more comprehensive breakdown of the FINCH mission, check out our
FINCH Summer 2023 Critical Design Review
.
The Mission
The FINCH mission objective is to conduct crop residue mapping over Canada. Crop residue mapping involves the use of remote sensing technology, such as satellites or drones, to collect data on the amount and distribution of plant material left in a field after harvest. This information is crucial for understanding soil health, managing agricultural waste, and optimizing sustainable farming practices [
src
].
At a high-level, the concept of operations for the FINCH mission is as follows:
Launch the satellite into Low Earth Orbit (LEO)
Take pictures of crop fields in the Short-Wave Infrared Range (SWIR)
Downlink those pictures to our mission control center
Process the images using a special algorithm (spectral mixture analysis, SMA) to distinguish areas of crop residue from soil and other materials in our images
FINCH concept of operations
ALT
Based on that mission profile, there are a number of scientific requirements we have to design our spacecraft and payload around:
Spatial resolution: < 90m x 90m or as small as possible
Spectral Resolution: < 10nm
Spectral Range: 900 - 1700nm or as wide as possible
SNR: > 30 or as large as possible
All requirements can be found in
Requirements
. Requirements drive all our design work on Space Systems. You can learn more about requirements here:
Requirements Engineering
.
Team
Space Systems is composed of several teams that are each responsible for the development of a specific mission system. We have five mission cores and their associated systems.
FINCH team structure. See for latest:
https://app.diagrams.net/#G12BaOC6FZubndbvEVJG0ntQMCYaRKnIIV
ALT
The diagram has no notion of a power hierarchy. While our responsibilities as technical leads vary in terms of breadth and depth, and our level of technical experience differs between our respective fields, we value each others opinions with equal weight. This is the kind of culture we have nurtured on Space Systems.
All teams can be accessed through the
Teams
database.
Architecture
Let’s go over the design of the spacecraft.
Overview
Allow us to introduce you to FINCH: FINCH is a 3U+
CubeSat
carrying a novel hyperspectral imaging payload designed to conduct crop residue mapping over Canada.
FINCH CAD V2023-08-26
ALT
The “+” in 3U+ is because we make use of the additional tuna can space provided by the CubeSat Design Specification (
CubeSat Design Specification 14.1
) for our attitude determination and control system (ADCS) module. One of the most important technical challenges we have to solve as an imaging mission (out of many) is achieving the high degree of pointing accuracy required, so we leverage a performant ADCS and novel payload design to achieve this.
This is a system block diagram that shows FINCH’s architecture at a high-level:
FINCH systems architecture. See for latest:
https://app.diagrams.net/#G1WX9SwAGlAm3Z5XkLx2Xr9eqT2i4Dqkhy
ALT
A lot going on here, but don’t feel overwhelmed. Let’s break this down. The spacecraft is split into two regions: the spacecraft bus and the payload. The payload is responsible for acquiring images, while the spacecraft bus is responsible for managing the power, data, communication, attitude, temperature, and general survival of the spacecraft itself. Space is dangerous, so this makes our work extra tricky. But this challenge is what makes designing space systems fun. See
Space Environment
.
Below is a diagram of the FINCH stackup, to relative scale.
To learn more about the architecture, see
Systems
.
Optics
Optics
The Optics team oversees all things light! We are responsible for designing, building, and testing our hyperspectral imaging payload:
FINCH EYE: About, Prototypes
. Our payload must capture light reflected off of our imaging site on Earth and do a little bit of light-bending before passing it on to our sensor. This is achieved via a foreoptic, slit, relay lenses, and
VPH grism
. Something cool to note is that when FINCH launches, this will be the world’s
first
grism-based hyperspectral camera in a CubeSat form factor!
The payload design is driven by
Requirements Model: Optics
which trickle down from the scientific requirements of swath, spatial and spectral resolution, spectral range, Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR), optical performance metrics, and space conditions. Our design process involves requirement definition, tradeoff analyses in
Python
, optical modeling in
Zemax
, component selection, benchtop prototyping and testing, and collaboration with subsystems including but not limited to
Payload Mechanical
,
Payload Firmware
, and
Thermal
.
Mechanical
Mechanical
The mechanical team is responsible for the design and development of the satellite framework and structure (not including the payload). The satellite itself must be compact while safeguarding the structural integrity of its internal and external frames. Material selection, research, and analysis must be done on the satellite to balance its weight efficiency and durability. Each component finds its place through careful consideration, ensuring stability in microgravity and vibrations caused by the launch. Many aspects of the entire spacecraft are tied together by us.
The team is currently working on designs that will support internal components, such as the batteries, PCBA's and startracker. This involves 3D modelling, prototyping, and a ton of iterations!
Opto-Mechanical
Opto-Mechanical
Opto-Mechanical is the team dedicated to the optomechanics of the FINCH Eye payload, integrating the payload to the larger satellite, while holding all optical components aligned and protecting them from damage during launch. Not only must all the optical components be mounted securely along the optical axis at precise spacings and orientations for valuable imaging output - requiring design of the housing itself and the optical mounts within the housing - but the payload must be pointing down the the -z axis with great accuracy. Payload Mechanical is also responsible for ensuring the housing structure can be easily and safely assembled, and that it will survive the large accelerations, vibrations and shock experienced during launch.
At present, Payload Mechanical is: wrapping up its parametric, detailed design, ready to have final values inputted; prototyping the housing and iterating upon the payload integration and housing assembly plan; running structural simulations (using ANSYS software) to verify the stresses and displacements experienced under various launch conditions are safe; and working closely with the
Optics
and
Thermal
teams to ensure the optics are not damaged or negatively impacted from thermal and structural effects combined (STOP Analysis)
ADCS
ADCS
Attitude Determination and Control System (ADCS) is responsible for controlling the orientation of FINCH in space, this is critical to the mission as it allows us to complete the maneuvers required to capture images, downlink information, and calibrate the camera. The maneuver that imposes the largest requirement is image capture, from that the mission has a point requirement of 0.6 degrees and a knowledge of 0.002 degrees.
Current projects:
Attitude Planing
ADCS Testbed design
Testbed structure
Testbed electrical
Testing procedures
Systems support and vendor connection
Thermal
Thermal
The thermal team is responsible for ensuring that the satellite can comfortably operate in the environment of space. Every component has a temperature tolerance and its our job to make sure these components stay in their nominal range. As an imaging satellite, FINCH houses a camera which must also be characterized for thermo-mechanical distortions (i.e.
STOP Analysis
). This involves running extensive simulations, creating candidate designs, and testing these designs in the real world.
The current design consists of a sensing block and a control block. The sensing block encompasses all the temperature telemetry collected from temperature sensors and help the team monitor system health on FINCH. The control block helps maintain a set temperature range. The current design includes active elements such as heaters and Peltier coolers, as well as passive elements such as thermo-optical surface tapes. With collaboration from other subsystems, the thermal team researches, selects, validates, and integrates the entirety of the design.
Electrical
Electrical
The electrical team handles everything that involves electrons! Our primary responsibilities are the design, test and integration of the onboard computer, the payload computer, and the electrical power system (covered below). We also must integrate with off the shelf components such as the radio module and the ADCS module. Once everything is connected up, we need to make sure that it all performs as expected in the wide range of operating conditions that we expect in space.
The current high level design can be found here:
Electrical System Diagram
. I’d just put them here, but a picture is worth a thousand words which is longer than the two paragraphs that I was allocated. We use these diagrams to inform what needs to go on each printed circuit board and what kind of information needs to transfer between systems. The design of the board is only half the work though — after getting the boards manufactured, we validate them to make sure they do what we expect, and work with other teams (primarily firmware) to ensure compatibility between systems.
Power
Power
FINCH’s Electrical Power System (EPS) is responsible for the generation, storage, and control of all the power that flows through the satellite. Our aim is to provide the voltage and current required to power the thermal camera, the ADCS sensors, the on-board data processing chip, and the communication (RF) system that will allow us to transmit data to our ground station. Everything needs power, and somebody has to keep the lights on!
Our system contains:
6 solar panel cells and an algorithm that harvest solar energy,
4 lithium-ion batteries and a chip to monitor them,
on-off switches for each device on board that needs power,
voltage and current monitors that report back to the on-board computer (OBC),
a fancy fuse to protect the satellite,
and more!
Just like the other electrical teams (whom we work closely with), we make printed circuit boards for each of these different components, manufacture them, and test them.
Firmware
Firmware
We’re basically the coding team. Firmware is responsible for designing the low-level software that will control the hardware components of the satellite and help them communicate with each other. We write code that will execute commands that will control the ADCS sensors, the on-board computer (OBC), the thermal control system, the RF transceiver, so that we can execute our mission operations effectively. We interface with the higher-level flight code so that the applications we write can directly command the hardware.
Our design mainly revolves around writing C code that can receive and transmit data to several hardware peripherals. These inter  faces are controlled by the flight code, which will determine the satellite’s current mode of operation and execute commands based on what we want the satellite to do. Our C code controls real-time clocks, flash memory chips, thermistors, and any of the other hardware that you’ve read on this page before!
Command & Data Handling
Out satellite consists of a number of microcontrollers (MCU) and peripherals, such as the ADCS system, that our OBC will need to send and receive commands and data to and from. We have very tight computational and memory constraints, and we need to write optimized and fast code to ensure all the tasks on the satellite are completed, such as downlinking and compression, when we intend. This includes interfacing with all peripherals and MCUs, and ensuring the correctness of all data sent and received.
Our framework consists of a real-time operating system called FreeRTOS, which will support all the threading and synchronization functionality on the satellite. This is very important since we might have multiple tasks wanting to run at the same time and editing the same data, so the operating system manages the resources to allow everything to run safely. We are also using a communications library called CubeSat Space Protocol (CSP) to communicate on each microcontroller between the threads and across chips. We design and implement the code’s architecture, data and program integrity, and all system functionality to do with the handling of commands and data.
Payload Firmware
Payload Firmware
The Payload Firmware Team is responsible for equipping our satellite, FINCH, with the capability of taking pictures! More specifically, we develop firmware to command the camera to capture images, apply lossless compression, store data on an external storage device, and prepare for data transmission to Earth.
Our system consists of
Camera (Image Sensor) - captures images
SD Card - provides storage for the captured images
Camera Controller (Firmware) - manages the camera operations
Storage Controller (Firmware) - reads/writes to external storage device(s)
Compression Module (Firmware) - handles lossless image compression
Command Receiver - accepts commands from the Onboard Computer
And more!
Mission Operations
Mission Operations
No access
The Mission Operations Team is responsible for defining the modes of operation of FINCH, developing the ground-station and leading FDIR (Fault Detection Isolation and Recovery). Post-launch, the Mission Ops team is responsible for the operation of mission control. The requirements driving our team relies on every subsystem and embodies the overall function of FINCH and how it is supposed to operate and perform in space. Our focus is on ensuring that FINCH meets its scientific and exploration objectives while maintaining the highest standards of safety and reliability.
For the development of our ground-station and mission control, our framework is based on NASA’s OpenMCT. OpenMCT provides a flexible and adaptable framework for real-time data visualization, which is crucial for effective monitoring and control of the FINCH spacecraft. Moreover, a significant portion of our work is dedicated to the development of Fault Detection, Isolation, and Recovery (FDIR) protocols which involves a rigorous process of identifying and preparing for potential faults that may arise post-launch, ensuring that we are equipped to address any challenges swiftly and effectively. Finally, our work also consists of refining and implementing the operational modes of FINCH. This critical aspect of our work ensures that every mode is precisely designed and seamlessly integrated, allowing the spacecraft to perform optimally under various conditions and stages of its mission.
Data Processing
Data Processing
The data processing team is responsible for bringing the data collected from FINCH from its raw state just after it has been downlinked to a state where it is ready to be used for scientific applications. Many of the requirements driving the team relate to augmenting the existing abilities of the satellite using capabilities on the ground, such as increasing spatial resolution or refining image positioning on the Earth’s surface.
The primary design the team is developing is the data processing pipeline. This pipeline currently includes 9 main steps that correct for radiometric (digital) and geometric (spatial) defects in the data and will incorporate data from additional tests that characterize the sensor and other aspects of the satellite.
